utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: I was wondering if you could tell me what brought you in.

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Sure, um, I have been coughing a lot. I've been feeling short of breath and I just feel really wheezy, so I thought I should come check it out.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, when did the cough start?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: I've always had a cough. Well, I guess I've had a cough for the past five years, but over the past three days it's gotten a lot worse.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, did anything happen 3 days ago that has brought the cough on?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Uhm, no, I was, I did groceries, I came home and then I started coughing a little bit more and I haven't been able to stop since.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, is there any particular time of day that the cough is worse, like morning, night?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Uhm, it seems to be worse in the morning.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and are you bringing up any sputum?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: I am. Umm, and it looks yellow and sometimes even green.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK. With your cough prior to three days ago were you bringing up sputum with that?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: I guess some, but it was clear.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and are you bringing up more sputum now, the same or less?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Um, more sputum, and sputum just looks different.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, have you noticed any blood?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No blood.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and you mentioned you've been you've had a wheeze, when you do you notice that?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Uhm, I also, I guess I notice that mostly last night, yeah.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, um and what types of activities have you had shortness of breath?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Uhm, I guess walking, doing day to day things has made me feel a little bit more short of breath than I used to feel.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK. And have you been experiencing any other symptoms besides the cough, wheeze and shortness of breath?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Um, I feel a little bit more tired, but other than that, no.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK. So a bit more tired. How has your sleep been?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: My sleep has been, um, pretty normal. It's been, yeah, it's been the same. I guess it's the coughing that's making me tired.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, have you had any ear pain or eye pain?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Ear pain, or eye pain? No.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Any discharge from either, either your ears or eyes?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK. Have you had a runny nose?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Or felt congested?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, have you had a sore throat?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Uh, no.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Or any difficulty swallowing?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Uhm, no.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Changes to your sense of smell or taste?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, have you had any changes in appetite?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Uh, no, I don't think so.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Alright, and have you had any weight loss over the last several months?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Weight loss, no.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK. How about have you had any fevers or chills?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Fevers or chills ah, no. No, nothing like that.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Nights, how about night sweats?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Have you had any chest pain?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Ah no, no chest. Well my chest feels, I guess sometimes I, it feels painful because I'm coughing so much, but nothing more than that.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, do you get chest pain when you exert yourself physically?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Uhm, no.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, so it's just after the coughing?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK and how would you describe the character of the chest pain? Some people will say sharp, dull, achy.

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Um, I would say dull.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and have you had any like heart palpitations, feeling like your heart's racing?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: And how about any episodes where you felt like you were going to faint or, yeah, pass out?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK. Uhm and have you had any swelling in your feet, ankles, hands?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No, nothing like that.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK. And then have you had any urinary problems?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Um, no.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Any bowel problems?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and then any joint pains or muscle aches?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No, nothing like that.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: And how about any rashes anywhere?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and then, sorry, have you had any nausea or vomiting?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Uh, no.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK. In terms of your past medical history, have you been diagnosed with any conditions before?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Uhm, I have high blood pressure and diabetes.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: I see. Are you on any medications for those?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Um, for the blood pressure, the high blood pressure, I'm on a beta blocker and then for my diabetes I'm on metformin.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, uh, do you, are you taking any other medications?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Um, just some calcium and vitamin D.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Any surgeries in the past?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Nope.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Any allergies to medications?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK. Are your immunizations up to date?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: I believe so, but I recently learned that I should get something called the pneumococcal vaccine. I haven't gotten that yet.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Yeah, you're you're right. So for um, in Canada or anybody or in Ontario, at least, anybody who's older than 65, it's recommended to get this vaccine to protect against certain types of bacterial infections type which can cause pneumonia. So it would be good something that you can set up with your family doctor.

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: OK.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Yeah, and so are you, so do you smoke cigarettes?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: I used to.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and how much do you smoke or how much did you use to smoke?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Um, I smoked a pack a day and I smoked for 45 years, but I stopped two years ago.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, that's great that you were able to stop. Do you drink alcohol?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Uhm, occasionally like once every two weeks.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and any triggers that you can think of you were exposed to either at work or home like chemicals or things that you were exposed to that you had to breathe, that you breathe in?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No, nothing like that.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, have you traveled anywhere?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Alright, and have you been near anybody who's been sick or has similar symptoms?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Uhm, no.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Alright, and anybody in the family have a heart or lung condition?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Um, no.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Any cancers in the family?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Um, there was a liver cancer.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and, I think that.. OK, and that was all I wanted to ask on history. Was there anything else that you wanted to tell me today?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Um, no, just um, what do you think the problem is? I've never felt this bad with my shortness of breath before.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Yeah, certainly so umm, it, it sounds like it could be maybe a viral infection that I brought on this cough and worsen the sputum. This could be a bacterial infection, it could be a COPD exacerbation and also one of the other things that we would have to consider right now is Covid as well and so we will do a PCR nasal swab for Covid and a chest Xx-ray and some other investigations as well and uhm, we will try to get to the bottom of what's causing your your shortness of breath.

utterances.speaker: control
utterances.text: Add differential diagnosis
